definition: Primary federal regulator and enforcer of GLBA requirements for non-bank financial institutions not under jurisdiction of Federal Reserve, OCC, FDIC, NCUA, SEC, or CFTC. Enforces Financial Privacy Rule (Regulation P), Safeguards Rule (16 CFR Part 314), and Pretexting Protection (GLBA Section 521).
official_description: Federal Trade Commission has jurisdiction over all financial institutions not explicitly regulated by other federal banking or financial regulators. FTC jurisdiction includes: payday lenders, mortgage brokers (not regulated by other agencies), tax preparers and accountants offering financial services, financial advisors/planners (not SEC-registered), debt collectors, credit counseling agencies, check cashing services, wire transfer providers (not depository institutions), retailers offering credit or financial services, higher education institutions administering Title IV student financial aid, payment processors and third-party payment service providers. FTC enforces three core GLBA rules: (1) Regulation P - Financial Privacy Rule (12 CFR Part 1016, identical to 16 CFR Part 313) requiring privacy notices, opt-out rights, information sharing restrictions, customer information protection; (2) Safeguards Rule (16 CFR Part 314) requiring comprehensive information security program with nine mandatory elements; (3) Pretexting Protection (GLBA Section 521) prohibiting fraudulent acquisition of customer information. FTC investigates violations through market surveillance, consumer complaints, examination authority (for entities under supervision), and enforcement actions. FTC can issue civil investigative demands (CIDs), warning letters, cease and desist orders, and enforce through federal court litigation seeking civil penalties ($100,000 per institution violation, $10,000 per individual violation) and injunctive relief. FTC publishes Safeguards Rule (2021-2023 updates) including breach notification requirement (16 CFR 314.5) effective May 13, 2024 requiring FTC notification within 30 days of discovery of breach affecting 500+ individuals.

definition: Federal banking regulator enforcing GLBA requirements for state-chartered banks that are Federal Reserve System members (state member banks), bank holding companies, and savings and loan holding companies under Federal Reserve jurisdiction. Implements GLBA through Regulation P (privacy) and Interagency Guidelines (safeguards).
official_description: Federal Reserve System (Board of Governors) is primary federal regulator of state-chartered commercial banks that are members of Federal Reserve System (state member banks), as well as bank holding companies and savings and loan holding companies under Federal Reserve jurisdiction. Federal Reserve enforces Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act and related privacy and security requirements through: (1) Regulation P (12 CFR Part 1016) for Privacy Rule - identical to FTC Regulation P for consumer privacy notices, opt-out rights, information sharing restrictions; (2) Interagency Guidelines Establishing Information Security Standards (12 CFR Part 208 Appendix D-2) for Safeguards Rule - parallel standards to FTC Safeguards Rule but implemented through banking regulator framework; (3) Safeguards and Breach Notification Rule (12 CFR Parts 232 and 248) for nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies - updated safeguards requirements; (4) Interagency Guidance on GLBA Pretexting Protection (GLBA Section 521); (5) Incident reporting requirements through Interagency Guidance on Response Programs for Banking Organizations Affected by Cybersecurity Incidents. Federal Reserve conducts regular safety and soundness examinations including comprehensive review of information security program, privacy compliance, incident response, business continuity, vendor management. Federal Reserve has enforcement authority through formal enforcement actions (cease and desist orders, administrative agreements, memoranda of understanding), civil money penalties, removal and prohibition of officers/directors, and ability to impose corrective action requirements. Federal Reserve coordinates with OCC, FDIC, NCUA through Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council (FFIEC) on interagency guidance, examination procedures, standards harmonization.

definition: Primary federal regulator and supervisor of national banks, federal savings associations (formerly thrifts), and federal branches and agencies of foreign banks. Enforces GLBA requirements through examination and supervision authority; implements Financial Privacy Rule and Safeguards Rule through banking regulator framework.
official_description: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC), an independent bureau within U.S. Department of the Treasury, is primary federal regulator of: national banks (commercial banks chartered under federal authority); federal savings associations (formerly federal thrift institutions); federal branches and agencies of foreign banks operating in U.S.; approves bank charters; regulates and supervises for safety and soundness; consumer protection. OCC enforces GLBA through: (1) Financial Privacy Rule (12 CFR Part 1016 - OCC version of Regulation P) requiring privacy notices, opt-out rights, information sharing restrictions; (2) Safeguards Rule through Interagency Guidelines Establishing Information Security Standards (12 CFR Part 30 Appendix B) with nine mandatory elements parallel to FTC rule; (3) Pretexting Protection through GLBA Section 521 guidance; (4) Cybersecurity requirements through OCC Bulletins on cybersecurity and information security; (5) Incident notification requirements for computer-security incidents; (6) Third-party risk management guidance and examination. OCC conducts comprehensive bank examinations including detailed information technology and cybersecurity assessments. OCC has enforcement authority through formal enforcement actions (cease and desist orders, prompt corrective action, removal/prohibition of personnel, civil penalties), criminal referrals to Department of Justice, and ability to impose corrective action requirements. OCC publishes detailed examination procedures, bulletins, advisories, and guidance on GLBA and cybersecurity expectations. OCC coordinates with Federal Reserve and FDIC through FFIEC on interagency guidance and standards.

definition: Federal agency insuring deposits at banks and thrift institutions and primary federal regulator of state-chartered banks that are not Federal Reserve members (state non-member banks). Enforces GLBA requirements through examination and supervision for safety, soundness, and consumer protection.
official_description: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) performs dual role: (1) Insurer of deposits at qualified banks and thrifts through Deposit Insurance Fund; and (2) Primary federal regulator of state-chartered banks that are not Federal Reserve members (state non-member banks) and state-chartered savings banks. FDIC examines and supervises all FDIC-insured institutions for safety and soundness and consumer protection. FDIC enforces GLBA through: (1) Financial Privacy Rule (12 CFR Part 1016 - FDIC version) requiring privacy notices, opt-out rights, information sharing restrictions; (2) Safeguards Rule through Interagency Guidelines Establishing Information Security Standards (12 CFR Part 364 Appendix B) with nine mandatory elements; (3) Pretexting Protection (GLBA Section 521); (4) Cybersecurity guidance through FDIC Financial Institution Letters (FILs); (5) Incident notification requirements for computer-security incidents; (6) Business continuity and disaster recovery requirements; (7) Third-party risk management. FDIC has enforcement authority through cease and desist orders, civil money penalties, removal and prohibition of officers/directors, corrective action requirements, and for most severe cases, termination of deposit insurance. FDIC publishes Financial Institution Letters (FILs) on compliance and cybersecurity topics. FDIC coordinates with Federal Reserve and OCC through FFIEC.

definition: Federal agency with rulemaking authority for GLBA privacy provisions (Regulation P) for most financial institutions. Supervises and enforces privacy requirements for large banks and certain non-bank financial companies in specified markets (payday loans, student loans, debt collection, auto financing, consumer reporting).
official_description: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), created by Dodd-Frank Act (2010), assumed rulemaking authority for GLBA privacy provisions (Regulation P - 12 CFR Part 1016) from Federal Reserve and other agencies. CFPB writes, interprets, and updates Regulation P governing privacy notices, opt-out requirements, information sharing restrictions, and consumer privacy rights. However, CFPB enforcement and supervision authority is limited to specific categories of institutions: (1) Large depository institutions with $10 billion or more in assets; (2) Non-bank financial companies in specified consumer financial products/services markets (including mortgage originators, payday lenders, private student lenders, larger participants in consumer reporting, debt collection, student loan servicing, international money transfers, auto finance); and (3) Service providers to CFPB-regulated entities. CFPB does NOT have supervision/enforcement authority over: small banks and credit unions (examined by prudential regulators); securities firms (SEC jurisdiction); insurance companies (state-regulated); motor vehicle dealers (state-regulated); retailers (FTC jurisdiction). CFPB focuses on consumer protection and fair treatment through enforcement of UDAAP (Unfair, Deceptive, Abusive Acts or Practices) authority and other consumer protection laws. CFPB maintains consumer complaint database; publishes enforcement actions; coordinates with FTC, prudential regulators, and state attorneys general.

definition: Independent federal agency regulating, chartering, and supervising federal credit unions and providing deposit insurance (share insurance) for federal and most state-chartered credit unions. Enforces GLBA requirements for credit unions through examination and supervision authority.
official_description: National Credit Union Administration (NCUA), independent federal agency, charters and regulates federal credit unions and provides share insurance (equivalent to deposit insurance) for federal and most state-chartered credit unions through National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund (NCUSIF). NCUA is primary federal regulator of: all federal credit unions; any credit union holding NCUA insurance; state-chartered credit unions electing NCUA insurance coverage. NCUA enforces GLBA through: (1) Regulation P (12 CFR Part 1016 - NCUA's version of Privacy Rule) requiring privacy notices, opt-out rights, information sharing restrictions; (2) Information Security Program Requirements (12 CFR Part 748 Appendices A and B) establishing comprehensive information security program; (3) Incident Response Program Requirements (12 CFR Part 748 Appendix B) requiring incident detection, response, and notification; (4) GLBA Pretexting Protection (GLBA Section 521); (5) Cybersecurity guidance through Regulatory Alerts and Letters to Credit Unions. NCUA conducts examinations of federally insured credit unions for safety and soundness and consumer protection. NCUA has enforcement authority through administrative enforcement actions (cease and desist orders, administrative agreements, enforcement agreements), civil money penalties, removal and prohibition of officials, and in severe cases, conservatorship or liquidation. NCUA publishes Letters to Credit Unions (LCUs) and Regulatory Alerts providing guidance on compliance topics. NCUA coordinates with Federal Reserve, OCC, FDIC through FFIEC and with state credit union regulators.
